journal-title-group.journal-title: The Journal of the Midwest Modern Language Association

title-group.article-title: Seeking Fame Through Infamy: Satan, Oblivion, and the Memory of God

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright Â© 2009 Midwest Modern Language Association

ref.mixed-citation: Raphael puts it, "wee have also our Eevning and our Morn, / Wee ours for change delectable, not need" (5.628- 29).

Sharon Achinstein discusses nearly the same passage in her Literature and Dis- sent in Milton s England, but sees in it "blunting the assignment of agency and responsibility and instead blurring recent history in innocuous language" (23).

Achinstein describes one rather excessive incident: "On the date commemorat- ing the execution of Charles I, 30 January, the actual bodies of Cromwell and the regicides were unearthed from their resting places and dismembered at Tyburn, their bodies and heads impaled on pikes for all to see in the City of London, where they remained, rotting, for months" (24).

Christopher Hill's The Experience of Defeat, in which he explains that "Milton's favorite Martin Bucer treats Samson as a type of Christ, the Saviour of the people, first in oppressing the enemies of God, then 'in his be- ginning rather than completing the liberation of God's people from the power of the enemy'" (312-13).
Achinstein, Sharon. Literature and Dissent in Milton s England. Cambridge: Cambridge UP, 2003.
Augustine, St. Confessions. Trans. Henry Chadwick. Oxford: Oxford UP, 1991.
Bataille, Georges. Erotism, Death & Sensuality. Trans. Mary Dalwood. San Fran- cisco: City Lights, 1986.
Berensmeyer, Ingo. "The Art of Oblivion: Politics of Remembering and Forget- ting in Restoration England." European Journal of English Studies 10.1 (2006): 81-96.
Empson, William. "The Satan of Milton." The Hudson Review 13.1 (1960): 33- 59. JSTOR. Web. 7 Nov. 2008.

England and Wales. "Anno regni Caroli II, regis Angliae, Scotiae, Franciae, & Hiberniae, duodecimo at the Parliament begun at Westminster, the five and twentieth day of April Anno Dom. 1660, in the twelfth year of the reign of our most gracious soveraign lord Charles, by the grace of God, of England, Scotland, France, and Ireland King, defender of the faith, &c." London: John Bill and Christopher Barker, 1660. Web. Early English Books Online. 8 Mar. 2009.
Foucault, Michel. Discipline and Punish: The Birth of the Prison. Trans. Alan Sheridan. New York: Vintage, 1995.
Freud, Sigmund. Psychopathology of Everyday Life. Trans. A. A. Brill. New York: New American Library, 1951.
Hill, Christopher. The Experience of Defeat: Milton and Some Contemporaries. New York: Viking Penguin, 1984.

Lewalski, Barbara. "Time and History in Paradise Regained." The Prison and the Pinnacle: Papers to Commemorate the Tercentenary of Paradise Regained and Samson Agonistes 1671-1971. Ed. Balachandra Rajan, London: Rout- ledge & Kegan Paul, 1973. 47-81.
Macdonald, Ronald R. Burial Places of Memory: Epic Underworlds in Vergil, Dante, and Milton. Amherst: U of Massachusetts P, 1987.
Milton, John. Paradise Lost. The Riverside Milton. Ed. Roy Flannagan. Boston: Houghton, 1998. 352-710.
Milton, John. A Treatise On Christian Doctrine. Trans. Charles R. Sumner. Bos- ton: Cambridge UP, 1825.
Google Books. Web. 8 Mar. 2009.
Ricoeur, Paul. Memory, History, Forgetting. Trans. Kathleen Blarney and David Pellauer. Chicago: U of Chicago P, 2004.
Schwartz, Regina. Remembering and Repeating: On Milton s Theology and Poet- ics. Chicago: U of Chicago P, 1988.
Shullenberger, William. "Satan's Death Trip." Milton Quarterly 27.2 (1993): 41- 48.
